author: @nitheesh340
text: LOL! Same story.. I am a Mechanical Engineering graduate with a few years of Mechanical core work experience and I have decided to switch over to Data Science. I even enrolled in a course on Simplilearn a few weeks back. Just as everyone has pointed out - "Mechanical Engineering is not a "Non-Technical" field. It has the same level of complications as Computer Science. Think about Rocket Science. That's basically Mechanical Engineering. So Mechanical Engineering is a hard-core technical field. My reason to switch over was due to my past work experience and my need to switch over to a career that is future-proof and evolving.

author: @yumitomoonuma3033
text: Mechanical engineering can be very technical. It's a very broad field, including applied computation physics, controls engineering, etc. These are very math and programming heavy disciplines. These types of engineers are typically R&D types or analysts. I think the kind you're referring to are more like the customer facing sales type engineers.

author: @jayantachakraborty4915
text: Hello Sir,   I have been an avid follower of your videos since a long time, and have taken a lot of inspiration from your work.  However, I do feel disappointed at times with the fact that you seem to be a bit biased in your approach to people from the Engineering domain. I feel you could do better if you could talk and motivate people from other backgrounds too, like the ones from Applied Mathematics (Statistics, Economics, Physics, etc.) or maybe from a different field altogether, like Biological Sciences (consider the importance of Biostatistics growing exponentially currently).  I hope you will take into account my consideration and take a more holistic approach further on. Thanks again!  Sincerely, An Economics Post-graduate student.   P.S.: Not that relevant with the video, but extremely relevant for the thousands of Data Science aspirations and thousands of your viewers.
